subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Way/Why
msgSnippet: ... Indeed.  Most people in Canada and the Western U.S. have a full merger of all three sounds.  In the rest of North America except Eastern New England, Ox is
messageBody:
leaves_or scripsit:

> I sought out this group because I was having a hard time distinguishing
> Awe-Ah-Ox. It's gratifying to see that I'm not the only one with that
> problem. (I'm California-born and Seattle-raised, so no wonder).

Indeed. Most people in Canada and the Western U.S. have a full merger
of all three sounds. In the rest of North America except Eastern New
England, Ox is the same as Ah, but Awe is distinct (and includes some
words that are elsewhere pronounced with Ox, such as "cloth" and "long").
Elsewhere in the English-speaking world, all three vowels are distinct.

> I have a similar problem distinguishing Why from Way. Is this also
> characteristic of the western USA? Is the letter combination "wh" always
> written with Why?

Yes.

> Are there any other cases that you would use it?

No.

> For me, "wine" and "whine" or "weather" and "whether" are homophones.

This is pretty much true everywhere except Scotland and Ireland (outside
Dublin). In North America, although there are no areas where "wh"-speakers
predominate, they are quite common in the American Southeast and sporadically
found (especially in older speakers) elsewhere.

--
John Cowan cowan@... http://ccil.org/~cowan
I must confess that I have very little notion of what [s. 4 of the British
Trade Marks Act, 1938] is intended to convey, and particularly the sentence
of 253 words, as I make them, which constitutes sub-section 1. I doubt if
the entire statute book could be successfully searched for a sentence of
equal length which is of more fuliginous obscurity. --MacKinnon LJ, 1940
